contains long account of an arrest on board
the Commerce Steam Packet at the mo-
ment she was about starting for Dublin, OF !.
female passenger who was dressed in sal


loi's clothes, and passed by the name OF
William Brown. The officers who took
her in custody, acted from information Of
the disguise, which they supposed might
have been done to conceal SOME theft. The
sailor was conveyed to prison. From some
enquiries, the house where Brown lodged
was discovered, the proprietor of which re-


| terrcd the officers to the master of the bril

A gentleman who resides IN the neighbor-

nu,ti;.ls: In the course of the day he enter

purchase gloves for the wedding. A young
lady was behind the counter. She smiled, a:

Mr.. Wesley had clerk, who believed ths
rector his master, to be the greatest man in
the parish, if not in the country; and himser
to be the next to him in worth and impor,'
ance. He had the advantage and privilege
Of wearing out Mr.. Wcsey's cast off clothes
and wigs, for the latter of which his head
was far too small The rector fndinr
him particularly vain Of one of these canon.
ica substitutes for hair which he had lately
received, formed the design to mortify him
in the presence Of that congregation before
which John wished to appear in every re-
spect what he thought himself. One morn
ing before church time Mr.. w. said "re
John, shall preach on particular subject
to-day; and shall choose my own psalm, Of
which shall give the first line, ard YOU
shall proceed as usual" John was pleased
and service went forward as it was wont to
do till they came to the singing, when Mr.,
w. gave out the following line -


"l.ikc to an owl in ivy bush''


This was sung--and the following line.
John pccping out of the huge canonical wig,
in which his head was half lost, gave out
with an audible voice and appropriate con-
meeting, twang-


"1hat rucful thing am Il"
The whole congregation, struck with
Johns appearance. saw and felt the slmii-
trdc and burst into laughter. The rector
was pleased, for John was mortified, and his
self-conccit humblcd. This is the same man,
who, when King William returned to Lon
don after some of his expeditions. gave out
ii lIcpwerth church--Let US sing to the
praise aud glory of God, a hymn of my own
cotnposng:--


/ "king William is come home, come home.
King William home is come;


Therefore let US together sing


The hymn that's calld 1s Dum"
THE REV. S. WESLEY.

Laura. of New YoiL, IS ali about her. iief
story as well as could be recohected, ap-
pears to be as follows; Her father IS hier-
chant in London. About three years ago
She left his house to follow her lover, VINO
vas the mate Of d vessel in the North Amer
ican trade, and hearing he had sailed TOT
St. Johns, she came to Liverpool. and TOOK
massage for that port. On arriving at ot.
Johns. she discovered the vessel had gone

learned that her lover was drowned -oh n.S

atelv determined TO become sailor loi hia
sake. aud assuming the garb OF man. en-
gagged as cook and stewart to the Was'ei VI
vessel .or London, with whom ahe remain
ed upwards Of twelve months. ne hs"t
vessel she ioincd, and in which Shc also sef'

back, brought her to Liverpool. but tEe mas"
ter. suspcctinG her sex cHtorted from ncr
the secret, and wished her to remain win
him, but she would rot consent, ana shy
was about to proceed to Ireland. WINE ID
prison she said her name was Selma hgus!a
Hamilton. She is said TO be complete sal
lor, taking her grog and using TOBACCO iihc
other tars. She states that she VIII nave
four thousand pounds at her disposal when



tends 10 ennp vessel aud take command.
She was brought up Tor sanitation on the
10th Of February at the Town Hall, when 1t
appcared that her arrest was caused by the
Captain of the Laura. The girl refused to
ten the Magistrate. Alderman Bourne, her
ftthcrsnamc, she said She could see no ncces
sty for it; She said She was sailor row anG
such intended to rcn,4n. Mr. Duticv, OF the

her father. At tbs She gave him look OF
surprise, aud then remarked to the magls-
tratc she had made choice Of her present
mode Of life, and meant 10 pursue u. he
Magistrate discharged hci

From one Of the mosc respectable dealers
in cloths, We learn that ENGLlSH
CLOlH HS of the sharitHs, nr ioWi"9dd dye,
have found their way into the Bitimore
market. There is 10 douht, we learn, that
thcy came from the same source through
which they had been heretofore introduced


into New York ard Boston. Ihc spurious
or logwood dyed cloths, after being made un
and exposed to the air for short time, be
cone clarrt or dirty red color, aud cShih-
1t a shabby appearance. Our informant i"
order to show the difference between the
genuine and spurious dyes, applied, in our
| presence, the test Of aquA-turtis to several
( pieces Of cloth of each Kind. The effect il
every instance WAS, that the indigo remained
unchanged, while the logwood dye was de-
stroyed aud turned to scarlet hue. These
spurious cloths, from the cheapness OF the
dye, are sold at low rate, but to the consum-
er they vii! always prove dear bagain.

full articles.headline: WILLIAM BROWN, THE SAILOR.
full articles.article:
The Liverpool Chronicle of the 18th Feb.
contains long account of an arrest on board
the Commerce Steam Packet at the mo-
ment she was about starting for Dublin, OF !.
female passenger who was dressed in sal


loi's clothes, and passed by the name OF
William Brown. The officers who took
her in custody, acted from information Of
the disguise, which they supposed might
have been done to conceal SOME theft. The
sailor was conveyed to prison. From some
enquiries, the house where Brown lodged
was discovered, the proprietor of which re-


| terrcd the officers to the master of the bril

full articles.headline: QUICK COURTSHIP.
full articles.article:
A gentleman who resides IN the neighbor-


hood If Manchester, and who, having paid


his addresses 10 IA young lady who resides not
many miles from Liverpool, and who it is
stated, had so far approved of his suit as to
fix a day, il the last week, for the perform
ance Of the marriage ceremony, came to
town on Saturday week, for the purpose of
making preparations for the approaching
nu,ti;.ls: In the course of the day he enter
ed a glover's shop not one mile from street
which is undergone great improvements, tc
purchase gloves for the wedding. A young
lady was behind the counter. She smiled, a:

Ccntlcmen--Iiaying seen in the National In
tclIigcnccr OF the 27th ult notice of report
ii Philadelphia, founded OH private letters, rel
alive to the breaking up Of Mr.. Owens estah-
lishment at Ncw.Ilarmony, take the liberty to
assure you, upon personal knowledge, that Mr..
o. himself was al Ncw-iiarmony on the 20th CT
March, apparently felcitating in the progress
which he says those principles he advocates have
made and are making. II is true that consider
able dmnu,ion OF the population has taken
place; but that change is considered beneficial.
both as relates to business concerns and the pro-
motion oi NIr. owens more extended views. A
Succession of more contcnted and more intclli-
gent families, are confidently expected Indeed
L is known to the writcr that the changes
which have lately taken place have led to an IN
crease ofindustIy and happiness to those thatre-
E.ain.


1t is the intention Of Mr.. o. to visit Europe, IN
the course OF the present month; but it Is also,
as stated ~ himself, his dc ign to return, as
speedily as his extensive concerns IN Scotland
viii permit, accompanied by the remainder OF his
i4ully, two Of lis sons being now at Harmony
A TRAVELLER,
HcsAington, .2.pr33, 1927.

female shepkeepers generally do, "hsh ,ney y
observe the face Of male customer he
gloves were soon displayed on the counter
and the fair one proceeded to fit a par on
the hand of her new customer. The gentle
man first looked at the lady. then at the
gloves, and again at the lady. Hiseye bright
rnrd--his bosom heaved, and sigh escaped
III another moment the gentleman was des-
peratey. incurably in love. lie forgot her
whom he had come hither to marry, and
became f,ithlcss lover. lie instantly oiler-
ed hi, hand to the fair glover. She Just hes
itated one moment, as ladies generally hesi-
tate when placed in such singular circum-
stances, and blushingly yielded herself to hiS
soft seduction.-On Monday last the parties
we're married, and drove out of town attend
ed by a splendid cavalcadc, to the rcsideaec
Of the hot and fiery inamorato.

full articles.headline: THE REV. S. WESLEY.
full articles.article:
Mr.. Wesley had clerk, who believed ths
rector his master, to be the greatest man in
the parish, if not in the country; and himser
to be the next to him in worth and impor,'
ance. He had the advantage and privilege
Of wearing out Mr.. Wcsey's cast off clothes
and wigs, for the latter of which his head
was far too small The rector fndinr
him particularly vain Of one of these canon.
ica substitutes for hair which he had lately
received, formed the design to mortify him
in the presence Of that congregation before
which John wished to appear in every re-
spect what he thought himself. One morn
ing before church time Mr.. w. said "re
John, shall preach on particular subject
to-day; and shall choose my own psalm, Of
which shall give the first line, ard YOU
shall proceed as usual" John was pleased
and service went forward as it was wont to
do till they came to the singing, when Mr.,
w. gave out the following line -


"l.ikc to an owl in ivy bush''


This was sung--and the following line.
John pccping out of the huge canonical wig,
in which his head was half lost, gave out
with an audible voice and appropriate con-
meeting, twang-


"1hat rucful thing am Il"
The whole congregation, struck with
Johns appearance. saw and felt the slmii-
trdc and burst into laughter. The rector
was pleased, for John was mortified, and his
self-conccit humblcd. This is the same man,
who, when King William returned to Lon
don after some of his expeditions. gave out
ii lIcpwerth church--Let US sing to the
praise aud glory of God, a hymn of my own
cotnposng:--


/ "king William is come home, come home.
King William home is come;


Therefore let US together sing


The hymn that's calld 1s Dum"

almost always Si.tin sight, except when nd I
den from the yicW by hollow i'll the SANDS,
OF which there are many, resembling 'lle
snacc LETT between two succeeding oiliowS III
q tempest; and as vessels sink between tne
rising waves, So as to be lost TOR 'loa'e"s
from the sight OF those around them SO even
GIN this desert plain the same eitert IS pro
tluceti by MANI fuirows, which ihtercep's i'S
otherwise ie, Ell surface. In ii0nt - inc car 4
avan, and Immediately preceding y, was
six-poun1 iron cannon, very loosely Nt'eu -
field piece, on heavy car, ana drawn py
four horses. On each side this, were par
ties or about twenty horsemen IN each,"host
province It appeared to be to Keep an eguAi
line, bY riding up and down the oreaath ana
tbe front, and checking those who were too
far advanced, "a, well as bringing up by q
quicker pace those who appeared to tarry
Behind. Following in succession came sepa-
rate trains Of camels, some Of which contain
ed more than fifty animals in line. IN the
centre a large space was le!t for the harem
of the Pasha, the principal personaEcs OF
which were conveyed each III separate Vc-
hicie, resembling a paanauin, closed on all
sides round with hoiow lattice work, very
gautiily painted and gllded, and 0orne be-
tween two camsls,


Al the attendant females, whether COM
panions, servants, or slaves, We're borne Oh
caraels in a kind Of tented pannier, one Of
them suspended Oil each side of the animal.
50 that the pair Of tents contained two per-
sons. who faced each other, and were shell
+ared from the sun By the canvass, which at
once covered them and cultained thtm from
the prying eyes of curious passengers IN
front OF the central group were PEDESTRIAN
band OF musicians, who walked between tiit
TWO principal paiaqTns as they Kept thtlf
pace abreast ot each other; and Whenever
thcir porien Of the caravan halted for q rev
minutes, which happened frequently from
the pressure q those before, or the interYcn'
zion of very triliing circumstances, they be
puiled the tediun Of the delay by an Arabic
song, accompanl ing their yA!cea With the
common Instruments in use among them.


AS it was considered more than prebahle
saat the known passage Of the Pdsha 5 ha-
rem across the desert might attract the BE-
tlouins of the surrounding country, un"tr thc
hope Of beng able 70 plundcr them q Their
Jewels, Exc. they were completely hcmmrd
inthe centre OF the caravan; and vcrr s'tonS-
" guarded also by two dctachneats q htty
men each under the separate commands I
lbrahim Pasha and Ismacl Pasha, the vice.
rows Sons, whose mothers were also among
the priac pal females Of those whom they
protected. On the right and left ot the cen
IRE, and about the same distance from tue
nearest limits ot the edge Of the caravan a.
'hc adyadced guard werc from rs front, two
parties Of horsemen formed what might PC
called the wing guards, as their province was
10 keepa good look out in their respective
quarters, and to protect that portion OF IN.
caravan nearest to which they were placed
Behind came trains OF camels, fastened ta
IL, ~ e,1 CT pf ALI " tG
party of about twenty horseincn, apparent
y for the purpose ot Keeping thc caravan as
compact'y as possible, while q rear goard, 1t
the distance OF Fl ON two to three mi!e,, bro I.
up the whole.


The route taken BY tie caravan was the
central or most generally treqnentcl one be-
ing to the rthwald Of that which l had
pursued across the Desert Of .oue2, and re
ssmbng it in soil, having tlrai and hard
gravel, over which artillery and baggage
wagons might be drawn with ease; indeed,
beside the Gell-piect car which was drawn
in front, there were several othcr wheel
ed carriages accompanying the present car,
j avan


Towards sunset we had on our left a long
line Of sand hills, whose summits were Point-
ed and yariegated in thousand iornS, and
ghcir outlines more accurately defined as e.
Nenlnb advanced, ,tOrlnen bedUtlIul COHtTdA!,
by opposing their yellow edges to the deep
azure of serene sky. At Muggrib, the hour
when twilight ends, the sigma! gun was fired
20 halt; and while the camcls retosed OIL the
ground without being un!adcn, the pilgrim,
of the caravan performed their abluuons anl
evening prayers, and another hour was al
lowed for supper, AS the former was duty
in which did not join and the latter entire
ly omitted for want of inclination, proiittet
by the interval to throw myself along upor
the sand, and catch 4 short repose; but It
sleep was impossible. Appetite TO eat hac
narc; to have drunk vine, With the nigh fe
yer which continued on me, would have
been poison, and Of water no supply had beer
laid in, from an expectation that the chic
10 whose care and protection had beer
recommended, would aiiiord it to me tron
his tent, las well az every other species OF pro
vision; so that subsequently,, when unable Il
endure any longer the parched thirst tina
oppressed u,e, was Obliged to alGht, anl
walking by the side Of the camel, 10 sucH
from a goat skin the putrid water whicl
our drivers had provided furahc asses AM
beasts of butden--they having, for their owt
use, only small kids skin iull, which tn
impossibility Of rrpleaishing IN the desei


made them carefully preserve.


When night advanced, its darkness WA
very sensibly lessened by the yellowls
Wilderness of the plains around as we'll as b
the nncloudcd shy. which welded rs a cica

4 WING ,actlhant in London was fined G50,
tncarly s}50l for libclling Baronct by writing
in private ltttcr:.--"You may be baronct, but
YOU are disgrace to Your rank, j am sure you
are net L gentleman" Tine liaronet had COM
blamed of short measure in some Of his wines.
The fine was reduced because the wine mer-
chant had offered an apology previous to the III
dCmcnt.

Inconvenience and severe illness, it was i'm
Dossible 10 be perfectly prepared for the
imDl essons which our Situation was so wei
calculated to excite; yet am sure they lost
for moment their poignancy, if they were
no. altogether forgotten, III the admiration
with which ! viewed so grand spectacle as
the one that this hour OF midnight present
ed. The caravan consisted OF more than hNe
thousand camcls, besides mules, asses,
wheeled carriages, &c. and the number OF
persons who accompanied 1t, mounted ana
ON foot, were certainly double.


The four points Of the hol'Hon we're inter-
ccpted bv the separate groups q! llbh'S tna,
acconnauied those respective DIVISIONS oi
our surrounding guards; although white the
waving movements Of the lights themselves
were distinctly marked, not AN 1hHlVlau'''
either OF the Arabs by whom they were
borne, or of the gnar,l whose path they we're
intended to Illuminate, could at all be seen.
Immediately around US. the crowded cara
van pursued its march in the most compact
and closest order, to the unbrokcn prcserya-
t;oD of which every Individual was induced
,c attend by regard 70 Ii, own personal
safety; when it was considered that We had
ent, red desert, before whose tribes, It they
attacked. fiirht would he incHrctual, and
upon whose naked plaigs, no refuge could be
\ found

From one Of the mosc respectable dealers
in cloths, We learn that ENGLlSH
CLOlH HS of the sharitHs, nr ioWi"9dd dye,
have found their way into the Bitimore
market. There is 10 douht, we learn, that
thcy came from the same source through
which they had been heretofore introduced


into New York ard Boston. Ihc spurious
or logwood dyed cloths, after being made un
and exposed to the air for short time, be
cone clarrt or dirty red color, aud cShih-
1t a shabby appearance. Our informant i"
order to show the difference between the
genuine and spurious dyes, applied, in our
| presence, the test Of aquA-turtis to several
( pieces Of cloth of each Kind. The effect il
every instance WAS, that the indigo remained
unchanged, while the logwood dye was de-
stroyed aud turned to scarlet hue. These
spurious cloths, from the cheapness OF the
dye, are sold at low rate, but to the consum-
er they vii! always prove dear bagain.
